episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.135
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.135 --> 00:00:07.713
Hi, thanks for
watching Linux for Beginners.

3
00:00:07.713 --> 00:00:10.665
It is an exciting course we're
offering here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.665 --> 00:00:12.858
And to tell us more about it is Don Pezet.

5
00:00:12.858 --> 00:00:14.148
Don, tell us about the course.

6
00:00:14.148 --> 00:00:18.730
>> All right, so Linux for beginners,
a series we decided to create.

7
00:00:18.730 --> 00:00:21.970
It's really not built around
a structured process,

8
00:00:21.970 --> 00:00:26.868
like normally it's really just designed
to help people get started with Linux.

9
00:00:26.868 --> 00:00:31.429
And a lot of people out there have not
used Linux even one single moment.

10
00:00:31.429 --> 00:00:32.368
But you hear about it.

11
00:00:32.368 --> 00:00:33.585
It sounds really interesting.

12
00:00:33.585 --> 00:00:36.090
It makes you seem really
cool if you use it, right?

13
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:38.630
So people want to get that experience.

14
00:00:38.630 --> 00:00:41.450
And unfortunately, most of the training
that's out there jumps into

15
00:00:41.450 --> 00:00:43.980
the higher level, it expects you to
have a lot of previous knowledge.

16
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.600
So we wanted to create
a series that didn't

17
00:00:46.600 --> 00:00:48.270
require a lot of previous knowledge.

18
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:52.640
It could let you hop in and start to learn
about what the Linux operating system is.

19
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:53.420
Where it came from.

20
00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:57.120
And get a chance to see how you can
use it or even if you should use it.

21
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:00.120
Because it's not right for everybody and
you might need to know it.

22
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:01.840
Can you determine that?

23
00:01:01.840 --> 00:01:03.264
Should I even bother looking at a Linux?

24
00:01:03.264 --> 00:01:05.108
And this course is really
designed to help with that.

25
00:01:05.108 --> 00:01:09.045
It's designed to be your first step in
the direction of learning to use the Linux

26
00:01:09.045 --> 00:01:10.939
operating system as your primary OS.

27
00:01:10.939 --> 00:01:13.473
>> Now who would benefit most
from watching this series?

28
00:01:13.473 --> 00:01:16.796
>> This series is absolutely geared
towards people with zero Linux

29
00:01:16.796 --> 00:01:18.110
knowledge, right?

30
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:22.730
So if you've never even installed Linux or
maybe this overview

31
00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:25.530
is the very first time you've heard
of the Linux operating system.

32
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:28.220
Then Linux for
Beginners is gonna be perfect for you.

33
00:01:28.220 --> 00:01:32.090
Because we're gonna walk you through the
process of understanding how the OS works

34
00:01:32.090 --> 00:01:33.120
and how to use it.

35
00:01:33.120 --> 00:01:35.400
And it can be intimidating.

36
00:01:35.400 --> 00:01:39.430
You go online and you see people all these
shell scripts and doing programming.

37
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:41.050
It doesn't start there, right?

38
00:01:41.050 --> 00:01:44.940
It starts with a graphically user
interface and being able to click around,

39
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:48.180
being able to run applications, and
do the things that you're used to.

40
00:01:48.180 --> 00:01:50.110
Maybe you already use Microsoft Windows or

41
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:53.710
you use Apple's Mac OS and
you know how those work.

42
00:01:53.710 --> 00:01:57.480
Well, a lot of that knowledge can transfer
right over into using Linux as well.

43
00:01:57.480 --> 00:02:01.380
There's a lot of similarities between
them, so that's where we'd get started.

44
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:03.960
If you've already got a reasonable
experience with Linux,

45
00:02:03.960 --> 00:02:07.540
if you've been using it even just
as a hobbyist for a few months,

46
00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:09.370
then you've probably already got
the knowledge of this series.

47
00:02:09.370 --> 00:02:12.740
And you probably wanna skip past and
go to one of our more advanced show.

48
00:02:12.740 --> 00:02:15.690
But if you've never used Linux,
this show is for you.

49
00:02:15.690 --> 00:02:18.400
>> Is there a certification available for
this course?

50
00:02:18.400 --> 00:02:20.860
>> No, we chose not to follow
a certification on this one,

51
00:02:20.860 --> 00:02:24.090
because a lot of certifications are built
around more advanced knowledge.

52
00:02:24.090 --> 00:02:26.680
And we wanted to tailor
this towards the beginner.

53
00:02:26.680 --> 00:02:28.895
So don't worry about a test.

54
00:02:28.895 --> 00:02:30.770
There's no quiz on Monday, right?

55
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:33.760
It's just getting you comfortable,
getting you where you're ready to learn.

56
00:02:33.760 --> 00:02:35.000
And once you get through this and

57
00:02:35.000 --> 00:02:38.150
you become comfortable with the operating
system and you're able to use it.

58
00:02:38.150 --> 00:02:40.440
Then you can start focusing
on the more advanced topics.

59
00:02:40.440 --> 00:02:44.068
And you can look at things like
CompTIA Linux+ certification or LPIC-1 or

60
00:02:44.068 --> 00:02:47.307
any of the other number of Linux
certifications that are out there.

61
00:02:47.307 --> 00:02:50.956
But at the beginner stage,
don't worry about certifications yet.

62
00:02:50.956 --> 00:02:53.268
Just worry about getting
comfortable with the OS.

63
00:02:53.268 --> 00:02:55.782
>> Now what kind of topics
are covered in Linux for beginners?

64
00:02:55.782 --> 00:02:59.683
>> All right, so
this show it's kind of a living project,

65
00:02:59.683 --> 00:03:02.430
we're always adding more stuff to it.

66
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:05.190
So as we get feedback from users who say,

67
00:03:05.190 --> 00:03:08.460
boy I'd really like to learn
how to do x or y or whatever.

68
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:10.160
We'll film content and put it in there.

69
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:12.906
But at a basics, we're gonna
start off with a history lesson.

70
00:03:12.906 --> 00:03:15.990
Right, so, where did the Linux
operating system come from?

71
00:03:15.990 --> 00:03:16.830
Who created it?

72
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:18.370
Why is it free?

73
00:03:18.370 --> 00:03:22.560
That kind of stuff cuz it seems really
odd, don't they have to make money?

74
00:03:22.560 --> 00:03:25.590
So we talk a little about that,
where Linux came from.

75
00:03:25.590 --> 00:03:29.250
And then, we start to take
a look at how Linux works.

76
00:03:29.250 --> 00:03:32.740
We take a look at the desktop, and
the various desktops, cuz there's many,

77
00:03:32.740 --> 00:03:36.850
many different graphical user interfaces,
and desktops, and windows managers,

78
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:39.710
and desktop compositors that you can use.

79
00:03:39.710 --> 00:03:43.040
Now, some of those words I just used
you might not be familiar with,

80
00:03:43.040 --> 00:03:43.720
we explain that.

81
00:03:43.720 --> 00:03:48.190
How everything fits together to create
what you see on your screen and

82
00:03:48.190 --> 00:03:49.448
the choices that are out there.

83
00:03:49.448 --> 00:03:52.557
Man, it just amazing cuz you
might hate one window manager.

84
00:03:52.557 --> 00:03:54.634
And you love another one, so switch.

85
00:03:54.634 --> 00:03:55.830
It's easy.
It's easy to do.

86
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.652
It's not like Windows where
you have one Window manager or

87
00:03:58.652 --> 00:04:00.550
Mac OS where you have one Window manager.

88
00:04:00.550 --> 00:04:02.500
On Linux, you have a ton, you can pick.

89
00:04:02.500 --> 00:04:04.490
So we introduce you to that.

90
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:08.500
We also take a look at how to install
software, how to remove software.

91
00:04:08.500 --> 00:04:12.110
That's kind of daily stuff that
we do in using a computer.

92
00:04:12.110 --> 00:04:14.710
You may have a web browser
that's your favorite.

93
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:17.360
And it doesn't really matter if
you're on Windows, or Mac OS or

94
00:04:17.360 --> 00:04:18.790
Linux as long as you have
your favorite web browser.

95
00:04:18.790 --> 00:04:21.840
So how do we get that installed in Linux,
how do we use it and maintain it?

96
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:23.410
How do we keep it up to date?

97
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:26.696
Those are all things that we're gonna
take a look at right here in Linux for

98
00:04:26.696 --> 00:04:27.283
beginners.

99
00:04:27.283 --> 00:04:30.544
>> Well, if this series sounds like
something you'd be interested in, and

100
00:04:30.544 --> 00:04:34.026
it should be, you wanna check out Linux
for Beginners, thanks for watching.

101
00:04:34.026 --> 00:04:39.600
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss the different distributions of Linux. They explore the Linux family tree, looking at how the different Linux distributions are related.
episodes.title: Choosing a Distribution
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:02.028
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.028 --> 00:00:06.359
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.359 --> 00:00:08.364
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.364 --> 00:00:12.236
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.236 --> 00:00:15.160
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.160 --> 00:00:19.450
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing our Linux for beginners.

7
00:00:19.450 --> 00:00:20.725
And specifically in this episode,

8
00:00:20.725 --> 00:00:25.310
we're gonna be taking a look at how we
would go about choosing a distribution.

9
00:00:25.310 --> 00:00:29.710
And here to guide us through this
incredible maze of distributions is Mr.

10
00:00:29.710 --> 00:00:30.700
Don Pezet, how you doing, Don?

11
00:00:30.700 --> 00:00:33.120
>> I'm doing great, Mike,
I'm really excited about this episode,

12
00:00:33.120 --> 00:00:36.020
cuz this is one of the most
fun topics to talk about.

13
00:00:36.020 --> 00:00:40.570
When you decide to make that plunge,
I'm gonna run Linux!

14
00:00:40.570 --> 00:00:44.796
It's not as easy as just going and saying,
I'm gonna grab Linux and install it,

15
00:00:44.796 --> 00:00:47.172
because there's so many options out there.

16
00:00:47.172 --> 00:00:50.196
In the Linux world we have what
are called distributions, and

17
00:00:50.196 --> 00:00:52.850
distributions are a lot
different than any other OS.

18
00:00:52.850 --> 00:00:56.870
If I want to go get Mac OS,
there's one version of it.

19
00:00:56.870 --> 00:00:59.258
Well, I guess there's old versions and
new versions, but

20
00:00:59.258 --> 00:01:00.901
you're gonna get one current version.

21
00:01:00.901 --> 00:01:04.093
If I wanna get Windows, well,
there's two versions of it,

22
00:01:04.093 --> 00:01:07.237
there's the server and
the workstation, and that's it.

23
00:01:07.237 --> 00:01:13.396
But, in the Linux world, there are
hundreds of different versions of Linux.

24
00:01:13.396 --> 00:01:17.886
And these are called distributions, where
people have taken the Linux kernel and

25
00:01:17.886 --> 00:01:21.285
packaged software with it to
create a full operating system.

26
00:01:21.285 --> 00:01:24.773
And different people do
it different ways and

27
00:01:24.773 --> 00:01:28.269
what you end up with is
a wide field of choice.

28
00:01:28.269 --> 00:01:31.469
Which is good because you can
get something that's exactly

29
00:01:31.469 --> 00:01:35.573
the way you like it, if you know what you
like [LAUGH] and if you know it exists.

30
00:01:35.573 --> 00:01:37.275
I mean,
it is a massive field of confusion so

31
00:01:37.275 --> 00:01:39.903
that's what we're gonna take a look
at right here in this episode.

32
00:01:39.903 --> 00:01:42.565
Is what are some of the main
distributions out there, and

33
00:01:42.565 --> 00:01:44.735
how we go about even
picking one to start with.

34
00:01:44.735 --> 00:01:46.900
>> That would be my first question then,
Don.

35
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:51.401
Do I have to scour the web and look for
these distributions in dark corners?

36
00:01:51.401 --> 00:01:55.188
Or is there maybe somewhere I can
go to see all these distributions?

37
00:01:55.188 --> 00:01:55.817
>> You can do both.

38
00:01:55.817 --> 00:01:59.992
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I've used Linux for a long time,

39
00:01:59.992 --> 00:02:02.671
I first got introduced to the Linux,

40
00:02:02.671 --> 00:02:07.696
I mentioned the first episode how
Linux really started in 1991.

41
00:02:07.696 --> 00:02:10.604
I didn't use it in 1991,
I wasn't that cool, but

42
00:02:10.604 --> 00:02:12.700
1994 is when I started with Linux.

43
00:02:12.700 --> 00:02:17.430
So not too long after it was out, and
at the time, it was a heck of a lot

44
00:02:17.430 --> 00:02:21.390
easier cuz there were two or
three main distributions and that was it.

45
00:02:21.390 --> 00:02:25.990
So everybody was kind of picking between
these three distros that were out there.

46
00:02:25.990 --> 00:02:30.250
Well, now there are tons,
hundreds, thousands.

47
00:02:30.250 --> 00:02:33.450
Sometimes companies will create a custom
version of Linux just for use inside of

48
00:02:33.450 --> 00:02:36.400
that company, these are private distros
that don't even make it to the Internet.

49
00:02:36.400 --> 00:02:40.162
So if you're crawling around the deep
corners of the Internet like Mike

50
00:02:40.162 --> 00:02:44.050
mentioned, you may find many distributions
are out there that are very,

51
00:02:44.050 --> 00:02:44.939
very specific.

52
00:02:44.939 --> 00:02:48.031
For example, what is the one,
I'm drawing a blank,

53
00:02:48.031 --> 00:02:51.985
it used to be the Xbox media center,
XBMC, they changed the name.

54
00:02:51.985 --> 00:02:54.113
>> Yeah, I can't think of it,
I know what you're talking about.

55
00:02:54.113 --> 00:02:55.670
>> Yeah, well whatever that one is,

56
00:02:55.670 --> 00:02:59.440
where here's a version of Linux that they
made specifically for video streaming.

57
00:02:59.440 --> 00:03:04.640
You hook it up to your TV, you wouldn't
wanna use it as your daily computer, but

58
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:06.690
it's great hooked up to a TV for
entertainment.

59
00:03:06.690 --> 00:03:09.030
You get specialized versions
of Linux like that,

60
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:11.130
that are really good at what they do.

61
00:03:11.130 --> 00:03:15.101
But not necessarily something that
you'd want to run on a normal computer.

62
00:03:15.101 --> 00:03:18.590
So on a normal computer though,
you can go to sites like,

63
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:21.810
one of the sites I always
recommend is DistroWatch.

64
00:03:21.810 --> 00:03:26.525
DistroWatch, I've got the website pulled
up here, DistroWatch.com, this guy.

65
00:03:26.525 --> 00:03:28.862
It's a neat website,
website's kinda cluttered, so

66
00:03:28.862 --> 00:03:31.480
it's a little intimidating
when you first go here.

67
00:03:31.480 --> 00:03:35.150
But what they do is they
actually try to catalog

68
00:03:35.150 --> 00:03:37.170
all the Linux distributions
that are out there.

69
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:41.608
Now, be aware that some distributions
are very stable, mature,

70
00:03:41.608 --> 00:03:45.502
supported by companies that
have been around 20 years.

71
00:03:45.502 --> 00:03:48.841
Other distributions were released
by a high school kid last week, and

72
00:03:48.841 --> 00:03:51.450
they won't be around a month from now.

73
00:03:51.450 --> 00:03:55.558
Because anybody can create a distribution,
that means there's gonna be some good,

74
00:03:55.558 --> 00:03:59.052
there's gonna be a lot of bad, and
there's gonna be tons of in between.

75
00:03:59.052 --> 00:04:03.330
So it is important that we make good
choices when we go to pick a distro.

76
00:04:03.330 --> 00:04:08.590
Now, if I just said, hey, here's the list
of distributions, it's intimidating.

77
00:04:08.590 --> 00:04:11.245
On the DistroWatch website,
they have this kind of neat thing.

78
00:04:11.245 --> 00:04:14.648
It's called the Linux family tree,
and what they did is,

79
00:04:14.648 --> 00:04:18.090
they created a graphic,
one of the users on DistroWatch.

80
00:04:18.090 --> 00:04:21.997
You can go to their website,
it's distrowatch.com/ I guess that's not

81
00:04:21.997 --> 00:04:24.609
an easy URL,
I'll put the link in the show notes.

82
00:04:24.609 --> 00:04:26.999
But [LAUGH] you can go and
view the family tree, and

83
00:04:26.999 --> 00:04:30.710
they actually list all the distributions
that they are aware of.

84
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:38.270
And if you look at this list, it is
massive, it just goes on and on and on.

85
00:04:38.270 --> 00:04:42.490
Well, its kinda zoomed out here,
let me flip to a local copy, here, so

86
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:43.990
we can see it a little bit better.

87
00:04:45.570 --> 00:04:48.698
And as you scroll down here,
what you're going to notice is,

88
00:04:48.698 --> 00:04:51.662
there a ton of these distributions
that are out and about.

89
00:04:51.662 --> 00:04:54.531
>> So, each one of those
colored dots is a distribution?

90
00:04:54.531 --> 00:04:58.255
Yes, each dot represents a distribution,
and

91
00:04:58.255 --> 00:05:03.481
notice how some of them go on really
long lines, like the zencafe.

92
00:05:03.481 --> 00:05:06.021
For the record, I've never heard
of zencafe prior to this moment.

93
00:05:06.021 --> 00:05:07.908
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's been going on,

94
00:05:07.908 --> 00:05:11.220
each of these dark grey lines represents
a year, so for years and years,

95
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:12.483
this one's been going on.

96
00:05:12.483 --> 00:05:17.142
Other ones, though, like if you look at
SlamPP, which, again, never heard of it,

97
00:05:17.142 --> 00:05:20.590
it went on for three years and
then stopped receiving updates.

98
00:05:21.600 --> 00:05:26.269
Sometimes people have a great idea for
distribution, and they launch it, and

99
00:05:26.269 --> 00:05:28.332
it's popular for a little while.

100
00:05:28.332 --> 00:05:32.427
But over time, people's needs change,
and things start to dwindle, and

101
00:05:32.427 --> 00:05:34.780
eventually stop being supported.

102
00:05:34.780 --> 00:05:37.770
And when they stop being supported,
you don't wanna run them anymore,

103
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:40.282
because that means they're
not getting security updates.

104
00:05:40.282 --> 00:05:44.130
So if you continue to run an unsupported
OS, you're gonna be in trouble.

105
00:05:44.130 --> 00:05:47.780
That's why it's important that we pick
ones that are stable, that are mature,

106
00:05:47.780 --> 00:05:49.330
that are gonna be around awhile.

107
00:05:49.330 --> 00:05:51.943
Or you might not have a choice,
you might have some very specific need.

108
00:05:51.943 --> 00:05:54.977
Look at this guy right here,
live CD router, and

109
00:05:54.977 --> 00:05:59.010
it didn't even go on a single year,
maybe six months.

110
00:05:59.010 --> 00:06:01.550
This, more than likely,
haven't heard of this one,

111
00:06:01.550 --> 00:06:06.110
but based on its name, was probably
a version of Linux designed to run on

112
00:06:06.110 --> 00:06:07.740
a specific piece of router hardware.

113
00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:12.090

00:28:50.627 --> 00:28:52.853
[MUSIC]

565
00:28:52.853 --> 00:28:57.506
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike look several different desktop environments available in Linux. They explain how the display server and windows manager make up the desktop environment. Then they take a look at several popular windows managers.
episodes.title: Choosing a Desktop
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.320 --> 00:00:01.324
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.324 --> 00:00:03.490
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.490 --> 00:00:06.580
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.580 --> 00:00:08.208
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.208 --> 00:00:12.670
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.670 --> 00:00:15.949
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.949 --> 00:00:19.910
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing Linux for Beginners.

8
00:00:19.910 --> 00:00:23.670
In this episode, we're gonna be
looking at choosing a desktop.

9
00:00:23.670 --> 00:00:27.382
And here to guide us through this
all-important decision is Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.382 --> 00:00:28.175
Welcome, Don.

11
00:00:28.175 --> 00:00:29.760
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Mike.

12
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:32.549
Yeah, this is kind of a neat episode,
because in the last episode we talked

13
00:00:32.549 --> 00:00:34.680
a little about picking your distribution,
right?

14
00:00:34.680 --> 00:00:37.750
We talked about Red Hat,
and Ubuntu, and Debian, and

15
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:40.310
all these different distributions
that are out there.

16
00:00:40.310 --> 00:00:45.990
But at the end of the day, for most users,
for most just regular Linux users,

17
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:49.530
the distribution doesn't truly matter, as
long as you're getting security updates.

18
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:53.010
What really matters to you is
what the desktop looks like.

19
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:56.485
And I know tons of people out there that
choose which Linux distro they wanna run

20
00:00:56.485 --> 00:00:57.603
because of the desktop.

21
00:00:57.603 --> 00:01:03.380
And they don't realize that the desktop
you use is independent of the distro.

22
00:01:03.380 --> 00:01:05.970
You can actually install
that desktop on any distro.

23
00:01:05.970 --> 00:01:11.940
So you can make Fedora look like Ubuntu,
or you can make Ubuntu look like Debian.

24
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:13.500
It's all kinda interchangeable.

25
00:01:13.500 --> 00:01:16.216
So I wanted to spend some
time in this episode, and

26
00:01:16.216 --> 00:01:20.176
talk about those desktops and what it
takes to pick the right one for you.

27
00:01:20.176 --> 00:01:22.560
And kind of how they work and
get a chance to see that.

28
00:01:22.560 --> 00:01:26.838
>> All right, Don, so what makes up our
desktop environment in a Linux system?

29
00:01:26.838 --> 00:01:29.550
>> There's a lot of confusion on this one,
right?

30
00:01:29.550 --> 00:01:32.530
We use the term desktop environment or
just desktop, right?

31
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:35.632
Which is what we see when
we look at the screen.

32
00:01:35.632 --> 00:01:39.760
But there's actually a couple of different
pieces that go together to make up

33
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:41.930
what appears on your screen.

34
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:47.092
The first thing is what we visually see
as the user, we see windows, right?

35
00:01:47.092 --> 00:01:49.570
Not Microsoft Windows,
but application windows.

36
00:01:49.570 --> 00:01:52.401
Each application runs in a little box and
we see it on the screen.

37
00:01:52.401 --> 00:01:56.720
And that is actually being powered
by what is called a window manager.

38
00:01:56.720 --> 00:02:01.490
And the window manager is what most
people think of as their desktop, but

39
00:02:01.490 --> 00:02:02.820
it's really just one piece.

40
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:03.415
Under the hood,

41
00:02:03.415 --> 00:02:08.260
there's an even more important piece that
we don't see called the display server.

42
00:02:08.260 --> 00:02:13.961
And the display server is
what's actually responsible for

43
00:02:13.961 --> 00:02:18.758
getting graphics to show
up on your screen at all.

44
00:02:18.758 --> 00:02:22.486
When you fire up true Linux, I'll call it
true Linux, right, just the kernel, and

45
00:02:22.486 --> 00:02:24.970
you fire the basest of support,
you get a command line.

46
00:02:24.970 --> 00:02:29.710
You get a text based shell, and that's
how Linux was when it was first released.

47
00:02:29.710 --> 00:02:31.858
The whole graphics stuff got added on.

48
00:02:31.858 --> 00:02:33.630
So they added a display server, and

49
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:36.500
the display server brought
us into the graphical world.

50
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:40.160
But the display server doesn't know
about applications and windows,

51
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:43.230
the early display servers would just
throw an application up full screen.

52
00:02:43.230 --> 00:02:44.810
You'd run it, and
it would run full screen.

53
00:02:44.810 --> 00:02:47.296
So with a window manager,
it comes in and says, no,

54
00:02:47.296 --> 00:02:49.852
the application can actually
run in a smaller space.

55
00:02:49.852 --> 00:02:52.765
And it'll be over here on this side of the
screen, or down here on this other side,

56
00:02:52.765 --> 00:02:54.160
or whatever, you move around.

57
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:55.590
That's what the window manager is doing.

58
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:59.930
The display server is rendering it
onscreen and managing the memory buffers.

59
00:02:59.930 --> 00:03:03.810
The window manager is basically
compartmentalizing these applications and

60
00:03:03.810 --> 00:03:05.230
making it all useful.

61
00:03:05.230 --> 00:03:07.290
So that's really important stuff.

62
00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:12.040
And it's true in the Windows world, in
the MacOS world, and in the Linux world.

63
00:03:12.040 --> 00:03:14.300
And so
we need to understand those components.

64
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:19.704
>> So now, do we have to pick a display
server and pick a windows manager then?

65
00:03:19.704 --> 00:03:22.725
>> If you search around on the Internet,
you would think the answer to that is yes.

66
00:03:22.725 --> 00:03:24.490
You'd think,
I gotta pick a display server.

67
00:03:24.490 --> 00:03:27.980
But the reality is there's just one
display server that everybody runs and

68
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:29.360
that's X.Org, right?

69
00:03:29.360 --> 00:03:32.740
I've got their website pulled up here,
the X.Org Foundation.

70
00:03:32.740 --> 00:03:39.530
Originally this was built as
the first display server for Unix.

71
00:03:39.530 --> 00:03:43.510
And back in the old days it
was called X11, all right?

72
00:03:43.510 --> 00:03:45.552
And you had X11 and
these various releases.

73
00:03:45.552 --> 00:03:48.744
There was X11R4 or X11R5.

74
00:03:48.744 --> 00:03:51.325
R5 ran for a long time,
R6 ran for a long time.

75
00:03:51.325 --> 00:03:53.915
Now we're up to X11R7, right?

76
00:03:53.915 --> 00:03:55.164
And then they renamed it.

77
00:03:55.164 --> 00:03:57.983
It actually went through a couple
of different names briefly before

78
00:03:57.983 --> 00:03:59.226
settling on X.Org, right?

79
00:03:59.226 --> 00:04:03.125
So this is more commonly
known as X Windows, right?

80
00:04:03.125 --> 00:04:06.285
In the original Unix versions,
it was referred to as X Windows.

81
00:04:06.285 --> 00:04:09.601
And the X Windows display server was
responsible for taking graphics and

82
00:04:09.601 --> 00:04:13.307
displaying them on the screen, and making
it where you could actually see that.

83
00:04:13.307 --> 00:04:17.535
Where we could have applications that were
running separately and being rendered.

84
00:04:17.535 --> 00:04:22.380
It actually runs as a server,
and when you view the screen,

85
00:04:22.380 --> 00:04:23.430
you're acting as the client.

86
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:27.060
Now, the server and the client on your
own machine are right there together.

87
00:04:27.060 --> 00:04:32.963
So on my laptop, for example,
I'm running the X.Org display server.

88
00:04:32.963 --> 00:04:37.400
And I'm running an X Windows client
to be able to connect to see it.

89
00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:39.954
But it's all part of my distro,
and I just see the graphics and

90
00:04:39.954 --> 00:04:41.790
then what you guys see on my screen.

91
00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:47.440
But if you wanted to, you could
have X Windows, the display server,

92
00:04:47.440 --> 00:04:51.970
running on one machine, and have
X Windows as a client on another machine.

93
00:04:51.970 --> 00:04:54.880
And so I could actually be viewing the
graphical applications that are running on

94
00:04:54.880 --> 00:04:58.330
a completely different system, and
that's really handy with headless servers.

95
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:00.972
I might have a server that doesn't
have a monitor or even a keyboard or

96
00:05:00.972 --> 00:05:01.852
mouse attached to it.

97
00:05:01.852 --> 00:05:06.629
But I can fire up X Windows as a client
on my side and connect up to the display

98
00:05:06.629 --> 00:05:11.110
server on that actual server, and
start running the applications.

99
00:05:11.110 --> 00:05:12.412
So they look like they're running locally,
but

100
00:05:12.412 --> 00:05:13.563
they're actually running on the server.

101
00:05:13.563 --> 00:05:14.830
It's kind of a neat use for it.

102
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:16.700
Not very common, most of us don't do that.

103
00:05:16.700 --> 00:05:18.220
But that possibility is there.

104
00:05:18.220 --> 00:05:21.710
Web applications kind of killed that,
we don't really need it anymore.

105
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:26.210
But for the most part, on your
machine you're gonna be running X.Org.

106
00:05:26.210 --> 00:05:28.763
There are a few others
that are worth mentioning.

107
00:05:28.763 --> 00:05:31.229
Wayland is one that's in
development right now.

108
00:05:31.229 --> 00:05:33.827
Now, you'll see a lot of
people talking about Wayland.

109
00:05:33.827 --> 00:05:36.168
Wayland is the display
server of the future.

110
00:05:36.168 --> 00:05:39.090
X11 or X.Org is really old.

111
00:05:39.090 --> 00:05:41.960
I mean, we're talking 30 years old,
it's ancient.

112
00:05:41.960 --> 00:05:43.868
And when it was originally designed,

113
00:05:43.868 --> 00:05:46.950
things like security weren't
really thought about.

114
00:05:46.950 --> 00:05:49.721
So remember how I mentioned there's
that client and server, well,

115
00:05:49.721 --> 00:05:53.070
there's absolutely no encryption
between the client and server.

116
00:05:53.070 --> 00:05:54.880
Well, if it's all on your machine,
what do you care?

117
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:57.840
But if it's over the network,
that's a real problem.

118
00:05:57.840 --> 00:06:01.490
Or if somebody installed spyware on
your system, it could be intercepting

119
00:06:01.490 --> 00:06:04.372
all of your display output because
it's all being sent unencrypted.

120
00:06:04.372 --> 00:06:07.450
So there's no real security, there's a
couple other things that don't scale well.

121
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:09.290
X11 is just showing its age.

122
00:06:09.290 --> 00:06:12.910
Wayland is the future, I'll agree
with that, but it's not ready yet.

123
00:06:12.910 --> 00:06:15.630
If you run Wayland on your system,
you're gonna get some instability.

124
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:17.030
You're gonna get some screen artifacts.

125
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:18.930
The video drivers aren't complete.

126
00:06:18.930 --> 00:06:19.830
It's not perfect.

127
00:06:19.830 --> 00:06:21.348
I'm not saying Wayland is bad.

128
00:06:21.348 --> 00:06:24.950
I fully agree, Wayland is the future, and
I can't wait for that to happen, right?

129
00:06:24.950 --> 00:06:27.633
It's actually really slick.
It's just not ready yet.

130
00:06:27.633 --> 00:06:30.980
So if you're learning and
experimenting, you can try out Wayland.

131
00:06:30.980 --> 00:06:35.311
But if you're working in a production
environment, or if it's your daily laptop,

132
00:06:35.311 --> 00:06:37.460
like my laptop right here, I run X.Org.

133
00:06:37.460 --> 00:06:41.220
So most distros default to X.Org, and

134
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:44.260
they give you the option
to go Wayland if you want.

135
00:06:44.260 --> 00:06:44.790
>> Gotcha.

136
00:06:44.790 --> 00:06:49.607
>> There is one more I wanna mention
that I probably shouldn't, but Ubuntu.

137
00:06:49.607 --> 00:06:52.667
Canonical, they decided they were gonna
create their own window management that

138
00:06:52.667 --> 00:06:53.656
was gonna be even better.

139
00:06:53.656 --> 00:06:55.630
Or I'm sorry, display server
that was gonna be even better.

140
00:06:55.630 --> 00:06:58.298
And they created one called Mir, M-I-R,

141
00:06:58.298 --> 00:07:02.062
like the Russian satellite or
whatever, or a space station?

142
00:07:02.062 --> 00:07:02.671
Well, whatever.

143
00:07:02.671 --> 00:07:05.472
So, they created [LAUGH] this
display server called Mir.

144
00:07:05.472 --> 00:07:10.373
And Mir was designed to be able to handle
display serving on laptops, desktops,

145
00:07:10.373 --> 00:07:12.688
servers, mobile phones, tablets.

146
00:07:12.688 --> 00:07:14.441
It was really supposed to be diverse, and

147
00:07:14.441 --> 00:07:17.361
they created a window manager called
Unity to be able to handle that.

148
00:07:17.361 --> 00:07:19.430
And it was the default in Ubuntu.

149
00:07:19.430 --> 00:07:21.560
Ubuntu is one of the most popular distros,
so

150
00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:25.710
you might be thinking, hey, that's
something I should really learn about.

151
00:07:25.710 --> 00:07:29.140
Maybe three weeks ago,
they announced they're discontinuing that.

152
00:07:29.140 --> 00:07:32.720
So it was an experiment, and it ran for
a few years, they're discontinuing it.

153
00:07:32.720 --> 00:07:36.370
So if you're making a decision
now over what you wanna pick,

154
00:07:36.370 --> 00:07:39.200
I would not recommend picking Unity and
I wouldn't even mess with Mir.

155
00:07:39.200 --> 00:07:42.930
Mir was never actually in
a really usable state anyway.

156
00:07:42.930 --> 00:07:47.250
So those we kind of put out of our mind
and we go back to saying we've got X.Org.

157
00:07:47.250 --> 00:07:48.506
That's really what we've got.

158
00:07:48.506 --> 00:07:51.932
>> All right, so
if there's really only one display server,

159
00:07:51.932 --> 00:07:55.852
then I'm assuming we do get to
choose our windows manager, maybe?

160
00:07:55.852 --> 00:07:57.379
Absolutely, yep, and on that one,

161
00:07:57.379 --> 00:07:59.662
you got a ton of window managers
that you can pick from.

162
00:07:59.662 --> 00:08:03.050
And the window managers were really good
about creating versions that support

163
00:08:03.050 --> 00:08:06.950
Wayland as well as X.org, so
they're ready to make that switch too.

164
00:08:06.950 --> 00:08:09.840
So you can pick a window manager and
settle in on it.

165
00:08:09.840 --> 00:08:12.830
And you don't necessarily care what the
display server is behind the scenes, or

166
00:08:12.830 --> 00:08:14.150
even the distro, right?

167
00:08:14.150 --> 00:08:18.870
If I'm running Red Hat or Fedora or
if I'm running Ubuntu or Debian.

168
00:08:18.870 --> 00:08:20.746
If I have the same window manager,

169
00:08:20.746 --> 00:08:24.770
I'm gonna have the same type of user
experience across those platforms.

170
00:08:24.770 --> 00:08:27.890
And that makes life really convenient and
easy.

171
00:08:27.890 --> 00:08:31.397
So when most people's preference
is simply how the desktop looks,

172
00:08:31.397 --> 00:08:35.065
what they're really thinking about
is choosing a window manager.

173
00:08:35.065 --> 00:08:39.900
And there are a ton of very mature,
stable, window managers available for

174
00:08:39.900 --> 00:08:42.599
Linux, so you've got choices, right?

175
00:08:42.599 --> 00:08:46.753
But there's really just five or six that
are truly popular that you see out there.

176
00:08:46.753 --> 00:08:51.607
And it's gotten to the point where
a lot of distributions well,

177
00:08:51.607 --> 00:08:53.967
any distro can support any window manager.

178
00:08:53.967 --> 00:08:56.852
But a lot of distributions have
started shipping custom versions,

179
00:08:56.852 --> 00:08:59.167
where they actually have one by default.

180
00:08:59.167 --> 00:09:04.702
So, for example, if we do like Ubuntu,
let me pull up the Ubuntu flavours page.

181
00:09:04.702 --> 00:09:08.638
So if you go and download Ubuntu today,
well, if you get Ubuntu 16,

182
00:09:08.638 --> 00:09:13.290
it'll actually have that Unity window
manager I was talking about, right?

183
00:09:13.290 --> 00:09:16.860
But if you do Ubuntu 17,
they're moving back to GNOME,

184
00:09:16.860 --> 00:09:19.710
a different window manager that's
pretty standard out there.

185
00:09:19.710 --> 00:09:23.340
But they do various Ubuntu flavors.

186
00:09:23.340 --> 00:09:25.356
You can go to their website, and

187
00:09:25.356 --> 00:09:29.399
you can download these variations
of the Ubuntu distribution.

188
00:09:29.399 --> 00:09:31.701
And you'll see Kubuntu, Lubuntu,

189
00:09:31.701 --> 00:09:35.425
which is I think they actually
call it Kubuntu and Lubuntu.

190
00:09:35.425 --> 00:09:41.700
You've got Ubuntu Budgie, Ubuntu GNOME,
Ubuntu MATE, and Xubuntu.

191
00:09:42.720 --> 00:09:44.880
Each of these are Ubuntu.

192
00:09:44.880 --> 00:09:47.020
It's the Ubuntu that you're used to, but

193
00:09:47.020 --> 00:09:49.830
it has a different window
manager by default.

194
00:09:49.830 --> 00:09:52.860
Each one of these is
a popular window manager.

195
00:09:52.860 --> 00:09:54.950
Other distros like Fedora,
they don't do that.

196
00:09:54.950 --> 00:09:57.960
You get one distro of Fedora,
and once you're in it,

197
00:09:57.960 --> 00:10:00.670
you can choose which window
manager you wanna use, right?

198
00:10:00.670 --> 00:10:02.670
But Ubuntu, they try and make it easy.

199
00:10:02.670 --> 00:10:06.990
So hey, if you wanna use MATE,
just download Ubuntu MATE.

200
00:10:06.990 --> 00:10:10.510
And it defaults to that interface,
and you get it and off you go.

201
00:10:10.510 --> 00:10:12.720
But it is all just Ubuntu.

202
00:10:12.720 --> 00:10:14.820
>> Still the same OS under the hood.

203
00:10:14.820 --> 00:10:17.040
>> Right, yeah, and so
if you've learned something one way,

204
00:10:17.040 --> 00:10:19.510
it's gonna work that way
across all of these guys.

205
00:10:19.510 --> 00:10:21.070
Now, let's talk about each of these.

206
00:10:21.070 --> 00:10:24.480
Some of these are more
popular than others, right?

207
00:10:24.480 --> 00:10:28.200
Kubuntu uses KDE,
that's its Window Manager.

208
00:10:28.200 --> 00:10:31.030
And the window manager in KDE
is actually called Plasma but

209
00:10:31.030 --> 00:10:33.290
most people just refer to it as KDE.

210
00:10:33.290 --> 00:10:35.980
It's a really robust one, I'll show
you guys an example of it in a minute,

211
00:10:35.980 --> 00:10:37.831
that's known for
just being very pretty, right?

212
00:10:37.831 --> 00:10:38.478
>> Mm-hm.

213
00:10:38.478 --> 00:10:40.790
>> It's pretty resource
intensive in order to be pretty.

214
00:10:40.790 --> 00:10:43.242
So if you have a 3D video card,
it'll take advantage of that,

215
00:10:43.242 --> 00:10:45.670
it'll take a little extra memory and
make things looks nice.

216
00:10:45.670 --> 00:10:48.160
If you've got an older computer,
doesn't run so well.

217
00:10:48.160 --> 00:10:51.052
But if you got a nice new computer
then it runs really well,

218
00:10:51.052 --> 00:10:53.425
it looks great,
it has tons of functionality.

219
00:10:53.425 --> 00:10:55.936
Lubuntu is based off of LXDE.

220
00:10:55.936 --> 00:10:59.709
LXDE is the opposite of KDE,
it's very small, very thin,

221
00:10:59.709 --> 00:11:01.905
not a whole lot of flashy effects.

222
00:11:01.905 --> 00:11:05.455
It's designed to run fast, and
if you've got old hardware,

223
